banterDialogues.professorPause: I'll give you folks a moment to think. Then I'll ask for your reactions.

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Why can't we just start now?

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: Some of us need time to think. Not everybody shoots their mouth off instantly--Blake!

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Yeah, Avery, you're probably going to tell us how everything in this seminar fits together, and your genius brain has it all figured out.

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: Settle down, people.

banterDialogues.professorPause: Remember. Don't react right away. Give it some thought.

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Why don't you ever give your reaction first?

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: This is traditional pedagogical practice. It goes all the way back to Socrates. The ancient Greeks--

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: Oh, for heaven's sake, Casey. Get over yourself. We know you love the ancient Greeks. You love everything, as long as it's ancient and esoteric.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: OK, let's simmer down. Focus on what

banterDialogues.professorPause: Hmmm. Let's consider that for a bit.

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: Kind of reminds me of an old joke.

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: Oh, no. Not one of your long history lessons, Casey.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: Yes, maybe save it for later. Meanwhile, I believe that

banterDialogues.professorPause: Well, now that's something to consider.

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: I think it ties in with what I said before.

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Watch out. More clever connections coming from Hartwell's favorite student.

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: Avery going to be teacher's pet again?

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: Let's all try to get along here.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: Maybe later, Avery. I thought it was interesting what

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: Casey, aren't you the one dressed up today?

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: I've got a date after class.

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Whoa, Casey. Steppin' out.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: We're not here to talk about Casey's outfit. Now, as

banterDialogues.professorPause: OK, take a minute to think about that. How would you respond?

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: How would *you* respond, Professor?

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: Hartwell's thinking before he says anything. Unlike some people.

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: What's the point of a seminar if we're just going to sit here in silence? I like to think out loud.

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: No one's stopping you from thinking any way you want. But let's let Professor Hartwell conduct the seminar.

banterDialogues.professorPause: Avery, while everyone else is thinking, can I ask what you are majoring in?

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: Engineering. But I'm thinking of minoring in econ. It's like engineering in that you think in terms of a system. I'm really liking this course, too.

studentBanter.speaker: Professor Hartwell
studentBanter.text: Mainstream economics is actually too close to engineering for my taste.

studentBanter.speaker: Avery
studentBanter.text: I gather that you think social systems are more complicated.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: More complex, yes. I would be happy to talk more later. Meanwhile,

banterDialogues.professorPause: Everybody's so quiet, not sure how to react. Blake, you're a senior right?

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: Mmm-hmm.

studentBanter.speaker: Professor Hartwell
studentBanter.text: Do you know what you're going to do after you graduate?

studentBanter.speaker: Blake
studentBanter.text: I want to go into business, but I don't want to work for a big company. What I'd really like to do is start my own company. I've got a couple of ideas.

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: I'd like to hear about that some time. But we should think about what

banterDialogues.professorPause: Well, that has everyone stumped. Casey, do you have plans for when you graduate?

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: I've applied to law school. But I might defer for a year. Assuming I get in.

studentBanter.speaker: Professor Hartwell
studentBanter.text: What would you do instead?

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: I need to make some money and then I'd like to travel.

studentBanter.speaker: Professor Hartwell
studentBanter.text: Where would you like to go?

studentBanter.speaker: Casey
studentBanter.text: Well, you know I'm into ancient Greece and Rome, right? I might like to see the sights there. But I'm also curious about Japan, so who knows?

banterDialogues.professorPause: That made the room go quiet. Drew, what kind of profession would you like to end up in?

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: Well, I have this fantasy of eventually having my own dance studio teaching kids musical theater.

studentBanter.speaker: Professor Hartwell
studentBanter.text: So meanwhile can you be like an assistant dance teacher at someone else's studio?

studentBanter.speaker: Drew
studentBanter.text: No money. I'm actually getting a teaching certificate and that's what I'll do the first couple of years after graduation. But you asked where I would *like* to end up. But we should get back to

banterDialogues.professorReturnPre: Keeping me on track, Drew, as usual.
